content.body: othermaciej: comet does have built-in compression
Hixie: ok, I guess you can use transfer-encoding: gzip
Hixie: but is it commonly used for Comet-like use cases?
it is for google
(I honestly don't know)
dunno about elsewhere
interesting
supporting use cases of google services is probably important to the success of WebSockets (if only because they are a decent model of what other large-scale deployments will care about)
i'm sure there is a version of WebSocket that both suits Google's needs and also has more than a passing resemblance to sockets and "tcp for the web"
gsnedders, do you maybe know how I could serialize the DOMNodeList which is returned by the php html5lib?
also, why doesn't it return a DOMDocumentFragment?
urgh... I hate it when Hixie goes on a reply rampage >_<
so I'm both second and eight place on Karl's list
shepazu: Have you asked MikeSmith? I can't volunteer right now.
hsivonen: what was shepazu asking about?
MikeSmith: help with a RELAX NG schema for SVG
ah
I'll talk with him about it
hg is so slow on a traditional disk. I should revitalize my MacBook by replacing the hard drive with an SSD.
hsivonen: just did that yesterday, it is soooooo worth it
hsivonen: On Mozilla-sized repositories?
Philip`: yeah.
(It seems very snappy for me on small ones, especially compared to SVN)
(but that's a much less hard problem)
Philip`: my comparison is with my Linux box than has an SSD
(my Linux box also has more RAM and a faster CPU)
I think I won't ever use a hard drive
couple of mac questions; how do I get commandline cvs/svn/hg to run and what is a good basic text editor?
annevk5: You install hg/svn/cvs and run them from the command line...
At least hg is trivial since you can easy_install mercurial
(maybe even pip install if you are feeling very modern)
And emacs is always a good text editor :)
(specifically aquamacs in this case)
(but I think that isn't the answer you were looking for)
erlehmann: no
well, i just used DomDocument in the end and cut off the superfluous html, head and body tags.
i wonder how to install them
got an editor
erlehmann: Serializing as HTML is possible. There's a patch for PHP awaiting review.
annevk5, nano is a good simple text editor. also, there is always macports … don't you have access to a real operating system with a package manager? ;)
annevk5: Either look for disk images
erlehmann: http://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=50973
Lots of people will come after you now for not suggesting vim, erlehmann ;)
Or install macports or fink or something
http://xkcd.com/378/
nano is not a good simple text editor
Nano is what you use when the choice is vim or nano or ed
gsnedders, pastebin.ca seems down from here. that patch will stay in limbo for eternally.
but thanks.
erlehmann: Yeah, I just noticed that. And noticed they had patch support in their bug tracker now…
erlehmann: I guess I'll dig it up locally later and post it again
well, in the end, saveXML is enough for me.
ugly realiable code is still ugly, but then it gets the job done.
TextWrangler is a good, basic text editor if you want to get all fancy and use a GUI, I think.
Peter` you should know that i am part of the „randall munroe gets unfunnier with time“ camp.
The important thing to note about that comic is that the nano guy is the only one doing work
The others stand around talking
what shiva said. :P
Also, i did not know about Rocky Mountain oysters till RIGHT NOW. CANNOT UNSEE.
aah
macports looks nice
"nano is an editor, not a religion"
erlehmann, I think I'm giving up on Ubuntu for a while until hardware manufacturers catch up with Apple
erlehmann, I'm not too married to any particular OS
well, Windows I wouldn't really wanna go back to
You could run Ubuntu on Apple hardware
sure
annevk5, the lack of package management really put me of OSX (and windows, too). but many of my hacker friends with macbooks use linux.
Or you could buy the same parts apple buys
sorry, it is „put me off of“
but I doubt it would be as efficient
Build your own
well, depends on your task. for programming, i have found package management immensely useful.
What kind of programming?
I mean in terms of battery usage and all :)
that kind where you need to quickly pull libxyz
ah, okay. got that.
I usually just write text and programming I do on a server
That doesn't sound like programming, it sounds like dependency management
Workshiva, libxyz-dev? ;)
It's not programming if you use third-party libraries?
"real programmers write their floating-point routines all by themselves"
I generally agree FWIW; unless you stay firmly in the Mac ecosystem, the packaging story on OSX sucks
erlehmann: No, not in that sense. But rather that you pull dependencies once per dependency, and the total number tends to stay rather low over time
jgraham, it confuses me to hell. after all, its not as if apple would not have the resources to set up repositories.
erlehmann: They could call it an "App Store"
hehe
and let people charge money for their apps
Call it the Book Depository
get libcaca, for the low price of 200g of nazi gold
Workshiva: You pull dependencies n times each, if you want to keep up with bug fixes and security updates and new features
what that guy says
and not-trivial programs use dozens of libraries, so it adds up to quite a lot
Philip`: Yeah, but you have n people on the team pulling them
s/not/non/
don't apple app packages contain every library they need, as with windows?
So the amortized cost is fairly constant
Workshiva: I'm assuming a case with 1 person
but the libraries get updated n times
Well, 1 person could just ignore the updates
And say 'patches welcome'
Task: Compare software installation overhead for a team of N developers using a) Windows XP SP2 b) Debian GNU/Hurd c) OS X 10.4 . Use big O notation. :P
annevk5: MacPorts for hg/svg/etc. TextWrangler for editor. (It installs a command-line tool called 'edit' for invoking it from he command line.)
Debian GNU/Hurd is O(0) because no one actually uses that
Whenever people talk about software having to work on Windows XP, I remind them that it's older than my little sister.
That's quite a meaningless analogu
*analogy
Your little sister could, literally, have been born yesterday
erlehmann: My program isn't meant for kids
So clearly supporting XP is even more important now
wonders what happens to things like the famous Boeing intranet once XP reaches EOL
haha
(since XP Mode will reach EOL together with the unvirtualized XP)
I recently got told that the european parliament still uses IE6.
hsivonen: They could just pull it off the internet and give everyone two computers
maybe they manage to patch the wine program loader so it works under windows as well till then?
that would be one hell of a hack.
It's not like XP will stop working, it will just stop being supported
yeah and most people are wary to eat stuff that is past its expiration date.
The UK government still uses IE6
They aren't wary of sitting in chairs past their warranty date, though
Your analogies are weird, erlehmann
But Microsoft will still support it whislt there are still big deployments
Who knows, IE6 might eventually kill them :)
wonders how much money the Boeing account brings to MS and how much costs it adds
Workshiva, you are not the first person to tell me that.
Even funnier are the ones who point out that I am „IRL just the same as in IRC“. As if that is somehow unexpected.
hsivonen, great, I settled on textwrangler independently already :)
i'll now struggle with macports
is glad that he doesn't share a name with anyone particularly famous
Because every time I see something on the list from "James May" I read it as "Captian Slow"
Which is annoying enough for me, let alone him
I'm the only one with my name, so far :P
Idea: pick a name from the Bible. Chances are, your child is going to be the first one to bear this name since Jesus' times.
My name's that way
Well sure there are lots of ways to generate a unique name
Take a well0known name and rot-13 it, for example
Challenge: Find a pair of common names that are rot13 twins
My (first) name's in the Bible and I don't think that helped it be unique :-(
wonders how many people there are called Judas nowadays…
Or Lucifier

gsnedders: I met a Judas once. It was at a loud party and when he introduced himself, I laughed and said "For a second there, I thought you said your name was Judas." He was not amused. I was embarrassed.
I know a Judas too, can't be cool to have a name like that
lol
Makes you wonder why parents make such a decision.. ignorance or self-knowledge?

gsnedders: in Finland this year there has been at least one baby named Juudas. Also at least one between 1940 and 1959. other than that, none. No Lucifer or Lusifer. Not popular names, it seems. However, since the beginning of data, there has been no one in Finland named Jeesus (the Finnish form). (there have been people named, Jesus, though. As part of Spanish names, I would assume.)
You can't name your baby "Jeesus" in Finland, AFAIK.
Hixie, you broke http://www.whatwg.org/specs/html5/current-work/ as a link
nw_: I'd expect that to be the case.
nw_, hsivonen: Why?

Well, the naming policies in Finland are pretty strict, as far as I know. Not an expert on the subject, but I've understood that you can't change your surname to, let's say, "Tiikerimetsä" (translates as "Tiger Forest") because there are no tigers in Finland. For example.
wow
that sounds crazy
In any case, you can't give your baby just any ol' name in Finland, it has to be approved by someone.
Yeah, grain of salt and all that, though.
gsnedders: I'd expect Jeesus to be deemed culturally inappropriate as a Finnish name. But if you claim Spanish heritage, you can probably explain Jesus as appropriate
I guess I'll have to change my name to Geffe Snedderström in se then…
Having some approval to protect children from their parents seems reasonable. Banning Tiikerimetsä "because there are no tigers in Finland" seems crazy
nw_: is there some stated rationale for this policy? do people in Finland support it? is it one of those "that's the way it's always been kind of things"?
there's a policy like that in Japan too
a guy tried to name his kid "Akuma" a few years back
which means "demon"
MikeSmith: I haven't seen rallies to change the statute
I see
MikeSmith, well, like I said, I don't know too much about the subject, but as hsivonen said, no one seems to complain.
Well, almost no one, I suppose.
OK
noticed that Swedish royalty have longer names than what is legal in Finland
I don't see it as an altogether bad thing, though, what with all the Pilot Inspektors and whatnot in the US.
heh
yeah
I wonder if Sweden has the same length limit as Finland for common folk and the extra length is a specifically royal thing
fixed-length names?
makes me think of hybi
annevk5: there's a statutory limit on the number of tokens
You are crazy
That I didn't know.
annevk5: It bothers me that I've never seen the specs for the tokens
hsivonen, in 16-bit code units?
ah
you can have up to 3 given names in Finland
(Swedish royalty have 4 each)
jgraham, but yeah, I agree that the whole Tiikerimetsä thing is a bit silly (if true). Especially since Eero Tiikerimetsä would be such a badass name.
the statute doesn't say what character reportoire is permitted, which bothers me
but Cyrillic letters apparently aren't part of the permitted reportoire and have to be transliterated
but that's not in the statute
wow, been a long time since I heard an installer DVD spinning
didn't wanna register so is installing Xcode from DVD
You didn't give up and use Ubuntu instead then :)
not yet
macports is next
then cvs et al en then I can review your tests and do work other than email
as a backup i have my other laptop here on standby
[02:40]  <annevk5> so I'm both second and eight place on Karl's list
annevk: yes the code compile on email addresses as an identifier. :((( Maybe I should do a second parsing on the list with names OR create manually a list of P(emails, name)
an nevk: the code is here http://www.la-grange.net/2010/08/02/mail-analysis.py
if someone wants to play, modify, twist, etc. feel gpl. :)
two places means I must have been way more active before I joined Opera
comparatively, anyway
I was thinking also about a data visualization through time for top posters.
oh yes
port install ftw
sigh. doing data-driven pref optimizations is annoying when you get to the area where you find some cases became slightly better and some slightly worse
hsivonen: s/pref/perf/ ?
hsivonen: What are you optimising?
yes, perf
tokenizer state transitions
Is that a significant part of the parse time?
found with html5lib that simply reading the input string seemed to be the most expensive thing and any computation was basically free, but presumes it's very different in non-scripting languages
Philip`: well, it's more like this optimization seemed like an obvious thing to do, but the rewards are less obvious than I expected :-(
Philip`: in general, the parse time is a small part of what the browser does, so no matter what you tweak inside the parser core, you can't make a huge overall impact
I guess it makes sense to just optimise for non-general cases where it's a larger part, if there's any such cases
(Nobody cares how long it takes to parse Wikipedia but maybe some people care how long it takes to parse the HTML spec, or is still a small part there?)
Reflowing during script execution is what kills browsers there
has anyone already repurposed the HTML5 spec as a parser perf test case?
installing subversion takes loooong
(i.e. making the whole thing display: none; and making it time itself?)
hsivonen: That seems trivial to do
lol
WOFF same-origin restrictions are mentioned in the introduction
Although having scripts is a bit annoying
including a reference to CORS and HTML5 et al
jgraham: sure. I was thinking I'd be lazy if someone has done it already.
http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-WOFF-20100727/#Introduction
well hopefully everyone ignores the obvious non-normativeness of that
Philip`: actually, I was kinda wishing micro optimizing the parser would benefit innerHTML
Philip`: the problem is, I don't know what benchmark I should optimize for in order to optimize "innerHTML<
Is there any way to find real-world sites that spend significant amounts of time on innerHTML?
hrm. the spec is so large gedit behaves slowly
huh, there are PutForwards in the draft. Need to get rid of those
Seems like some kind of instrumented browser would be very helpful, to tell people what kind of behaviour ought to be tested in benchmarks
Philip`: indeed
smaug: Huh?
Does anyone do that yet, or are benchmarks all just made up?
smaug, what draft?
What's the problem with PutForwards?
tml5 draft
PutForwards is evil. A sign of bad API
html5
why is it bad?
consistency
it breaks consistency
Philip`: The V8 benchmark did that with the regexp tests iirc
set and get start doing very different things
smaug: It is mostly part of the legacy platform at this point though
not really
Have we introduced it in more places?
I can understand it for .location
yes
for .location it is for legacy
but I think it is rather elegant
I think it is terrible
#javascript has a lot of visitors asking why they can't do window.location.indexOf
yeah, we shouldn't introduce similar problems as what .location has
hmm. the spec has lots of images these days
(removing the srcs for those so that they don't bother parser timing)
unless anything unforeseen happens XMLHttpRequest will go to CR today
annevk5: cool. finally.
yeah just checked
>4 years since first W3C draft
I thought it was much less
hmm
wonders about XMLHttpRequest.priority
macports doesn't do tab-autocompletion
wtf
mercurial requires freetype
euh
I've been neglecting to add the NE keyword to bugs recently
or for quite a while now, actually
and nobody else has been doing it either
we need to start doing it again
Are there ne NE bugs left?
there are some still open
but we have a lot of existing open bugs that aren't marked with it that should be
unless somebody has a better idea for how we can distinguish editorial bugs
we basically just want to be able to ignore the editorial bugs
because really only the editors need to care about those
What percentage of bugs are filed via the inline tool now?
yay
edit ...
hg clone ...
cvs ...
prolly requires some further setup stuff but the basics are there
Workshiva: dunno… maybe 50%
So I guess that means asking the bug reporter to mark NE or not is not viable
annevk5: http://test.w3.org/webapps/tests/XMLHttpRequest/info.htm is quite empty, how can it go in CR ?
exit criteria
not entrance
I find it weird to set an exit criteria date when we don't have a date for the availability of the test suite
it's just the minimum amount of time
MikeSmith, you around?
each time I set up a new laptop CVS is a pain
someone please move dev.w3.org out of CVS hell so I no longer have to deal
annevk5: here now
I guess I could probably set up some rewrites to point selected dev.w3.org stuff to dvcs.w3.org
the problem now is that first cvs complaints my ssh file is not protected
and when I do protect it I get prompted for a password when I run the cvs lines
and none of the passwords I can think of are correct
Did you protect the file from yourself too?
now it just says "permission denied (publickey)"
even if I set chmod to 777
argh
it needs to be 600, right?
i guess, but it's no longer working
"permission denied (publickey)" means that the server denied access based on your public key, not that the client can't access your public key, I think.
ok, but that makes no sense
it works fine elsewhere
if you do "ssh -v -v -v cvs.w3.org" and send me the output, maybe I can figure out something
oh lol
or I can ask systems team
it was sudo that was the problem
Using the same public key as elsewhere?
so I guess this was my fault
Philip`, yeah, I just copied stuff from Ubuntu
thought that was generally considered not ideal from a security perspective
well, I'm only using this mess for dev.w3.org
when someone takes over editing we'll find out soon enough :)
Fair enough :-)
where can I store environment variables in Mac OS X?
having CVS_RSH=ssh set by default somewhere would be nice :)
annevk5: .bashrc probably
or .bashprofile
annevk5: ~/.profile
thanks
annevk: setting env vars in ~/.MacOSX/environment.plist will ensure that non-shell processes launched from the Dock also see them
Philip`: What did you do to make the annotated spec for the canvas tests?
Oh I guess I can read the source
jgraham: I don't quite remember
I think it involved regexps
MikeSmith: You around?  I dunno if you can touch the listserv stuff, but I got an odd email today that I think points to a problem on the listserv.
TabAtkins: I don't have access to the mailing-list backend
what was odd about the message?
Someone just emailed me saying they'd received literally hundreds of copies of one of my emails to the CSSWG list over the last few weeks.
jgraham: (Also, lots of manual annotation-markup)
can anyone explain what em does/means? as opposed to px
im having trouble understanding the explanations online
An em is the current font size.
Philip`: Hmm
So, for an element with font-size:16px, 1em = 16px.
Philip`: So not easy to generalise to the whole spec?
jgraham: What do you mean by easy, and by generalise?
The basic annotation approach should work on any HTML document, I think
TabAtkins: so how do you set a font-size and an em size?
Otherwise, em is just an absolute length unit and works the exact same way as px/in/etc.
im guessing em just means scaling
dandaman: Through CSS.
Philip`: The desired end result I have is a way to have a list of tests and a list of positions in the spec (somehow) and associate the two
well you use font-size:15px
Philip`: So that one can see "oh that test tests this statement"
then what is the tag for em
Huh?
"em" is a unit, just like px.  You just use it like "margin-top: 1.5em;"

jgraham: For "positions in the spec", is my approach of copying the relevant assertion text from the spec into a separate text file and adding some annotations adequate, or would you want something more/less fragile or requiring more/less effort?
em tag is for emphasis.
oh
Oh, did you mean <em>?
no, you understood me correctly
em unit is for scaling.
how does the scaling work KaOSoFt?
Dude, I just told you - 1em is always equivalent to the font-size of the element you're specifying the property on.
What TabAtkins said: "<TabAtkins> So, for an element with font-size:16px, 1em = 16px."

jgraham: (I think it's worked well enough for the canvas section - it doesn't take that much effort to maintain the annotation file, and it means it can automatically generate warnings when the spec text changes and lets me know that some tests are possibly invalid now)
i know, but where do i set the em value?
So 2em would be 32px.
You don't set the "em" value.  *It's equivalent to the font-size.*
ohhh, 1 em is ALWAYS 16px?
No, it's equal to 16px if the font-size for that element is 16px.
If you set it like that before.
If the font-size for that element is 30px, then 1em = 30px.
If it's font-size:8px, then 1em=8px for that element.
ok lets say i have my inline style like this
<div style="font-size:12px">
Philip`: Oh that sounds promising
The size of the em unit is relative to the element it is being used on.
so everything INSIDE of that div tag using the em unit will be in terms of 12px?
jgraham: (http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/html/file/tip/tests/submission/PhilipTaylor/tools/canvas/spec.yaml if you didn't see that file yet)
If nothing else changes the font-size inside there.  Also, any properties on the <div> itself that use the em unit will get 1em=12px
Whatever is font-size related, yes.
Maybe if one is clever and writes a js frontend for making the annotation file, one can click on a bit of the spec, grab the right text and add a list of tetss or something
Philip`: I saw it existed
KaOSoFt: No need for it to be font-size related.  You can use ems for anything.
(like the status annotations, but a bit more complex)
jgraham: ("<^>" means "put the test marker here", "<...>" means match any string of characters, "*must*" means that's the relevant keyword, etc)
ok, thanks
jgraham: (plus there's some ugly hacks with 'previously' for sentences that aren't uniquely identified by their text)
foo!
^^^ The div's border will be 12px wide, the p's border will be 8px wide.
TabAtkins- Oh, wait, yeah, no idea how come I was thinking in other elements (images, for instance) have anything to do with font.

jgraham: It makes more sense to me that the test case identifies what part of the spec it's testing, rather than the spec identifying the tests, because it seems less likely to get out of sync if the test is updated
Philip`: In either case I think we need an intermediate file
Because the tests in general can't identify which part of the spec they are testing
(we can't really add that metadata to all tests)
Yeah, if we want it to be more specific than linking to a fragment ID
With the canvas section it's fairly easy to tie each "must" to a set of tests, so sentence-level annotation is reasonable
Don't know how well that'll generalise to the rest of the spec
For some parts it is reasonable
For the parser not so much
Some tetss have a one to many relationship with sections
Solved problem in the CSS test format - the tests carry links to the spec sections they're testing.
TabAtkins: "the tests in general can't identify which part of the spec they are testing"
Yeah, that statement doesn't make any sense to me.
And greater than fragment-id level precision is desirable anyway
Okay, we suffice with section-level precision. (Nearest heading.)
TabAtkins: Well there are tests like the parser tests which a) are not in a format that is conducive to adding that data and b) test many parts of the algorithm

jgraham: I don't think one-to-many is necessarily a problem - the way I usually try to write tests is by looking at a sentence (or word etc), then writing enough tests so that an implementation which does everything perfectly except for that word/sentence/etc will fail
and it doesn't matter if the test case also depends on many other spec requirements
and then there are tests that require quite specific DOM setup
not sure if im asking in the right place, but is there a way to make text scale with screen size(besides with javascript)
With the parser you could write tests for line N of the spec by finding cases where a parser that implements everything except line N will fail
i would hate to have to go through every element in javascript and multiply by a factor of the screen size :\
dandaman: Ideally what you want is to use the vh/vw units, which scale with the size of the screen.  Nobody implements them yet, though.
But it doesn't work if buggy behaviour is caused by a complex interaction of steps and you can't point to a specific place in the spec where it's clearly wrong
Philip`: It seems unlikely that anyone will start again with the parser tests
and also, what you said

I think that some browsers implement the rem unit, which is just like em but is always based on the font-size of the root element.  Then you can just change the font-size of the <html> element via js.
isn't sure how often that situation occurs
Otherwise, you're stuck changing them all.
Actually I suppose it occurs a lot when testing negative handling
dandaman: Are you wanting to make *everything* relative to the screen size, or just certain elements?
vh and vw units you say hmmm
TabAtkins: everything
like making sure the <foobar> tag isn't parsed specially, where foobar is some non-standard tag that some browsers might handle crazily
dandaman: What's the use-case?
since then you can't point to a specific place in the spec about it
jgraham: All we need to do is write a one-to-one implementation of the spec, run the test suite through it, then delete or buggify line N of the implementation and see which tests fail
You can point at the "any other tag" requirements?
and then we know which lines each test is testing
and if no tests fail then write more tests
Easy :-)
TabAtkins: just when the page is loaded
dandaman: I mean, why are you wanting to scale everything by the page size?
is making sure you're doing something reasonable before he offers his next suggestion.
TabAtkins: its for a mobile website, and different phones=different screen widths
Just to ask, are you aware of ppk's work on dealing with mobile phones and their horrible lies about their sizes?
no i am not :(
Go read some of the recent stuff in the quirksmode blog.
I've heard of Java testing tools which mutate the bytecode (e.g. randomly flip a conditional) and if that doesn't cause any test cases to fail then your test cases are insufficient
(or your code is redundant)
I wonder if something like that could work on the validator.nu parser...
TabAtkins: do you remember the article name?
dandaman: http://www.quirksmode.org/mobile/viewports.html
espadrine: Ah, you just beat me.  I'd been chasing down through his twitter feed.
Also viewports2.html
ty
so what it looks like is i just need to set my style widths to percentages
and i'll be good
Yeah, that should generally work.  You'll have to be a little careful, but it should be okay.
did not work :\
looks good on browser, not so much on emulator
doh, was using device-width
Why does this give "submit" instead of "" on Firefox, Chrome, and Opera?  That seems wrong per spec.  data:text/html,<!doctype html><script>alert(document.createElement('button').type);</script>
Is it a spec bug or browser bug?
AryehGregor, looks like a spec bug, button.type should be limited to only known values, like input.type
Firefox 3.6 doesn't treat it that way, but Firefox 4 does.
I'll file a spec bug.
(so do the other browsers I tested)
firefox 4 is using the html5 parser
That's surely irrelevant to this.
fairly easy to check if that is the cause of the change in behavior in firefox 4, about:config filter on html5 double click to flip the pref
volkmar probably changed it to match the spec
AryehGregor, I just filed one
Where?
I did too.  :/
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10290
AryehGregor: i changed that to match the specs
volkmar, which spec?
Ms2ger: btw, i think bug 9635 is more "fixed" than worksforme
HTML5 seems to say that Firefox was more correct before . . .
AryehGregor: hmm, s/to match the specs//, i don't really remember, i did that months ago
It matches other browsers better.
Matches the spec worse, but the spec doesn't match reality here and is probably what should be changed.
AryehGregor: why not having button.type limited to only known values?
I don't understand the question.  Having button.type limited to known values matches browser behavior, but not the spec.
Thus, the spec should be changed.  Right?
AryehGregor: I hope, I don't see why button.type shouldn't be limited to only known values
it would behave like input.type which seems better
Exactly
I think we should change all enumerable attributes to be limited like that
I completely agree
it makes sense to ignore on setting to unknown value
it is what <canvas> does as well
and gives the ability to do feature testing
I guess we should just implement it so the spec can remove the whole concept of "limited to known values" and make it part of the enumerable attributes definition
That would require changing a lot of attributes' behavior.  Would it break anything?
WebKit seems to treat audio.preload, video.preload, form.enctype as limited to known values too.
(which other browsers don't, and nor does the spec)
actually, some time ago i proposed (in a mail) to move the default behavior to be limited to only known values
